Description: MOSTLY AT A PARK LEVEL, PROJECTS ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGE OF RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES ACROSS ALL ASPECTS OF CULTURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO INVENTORY, MONITORING, RESEARCH, REHABILITATION, RECONSTRUCTION, RESTORATION, PRESERVATION, DOCUMENTATION, DATA RECOVERY, EDUCATION, AND CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION AND ADAPTATION. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE TRIBAL MONITORING FOR COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSE, COMPENSATION, AND LIABILITY ACT SOIL SAMPLING AND REMEDIATION TREATMENTS WITHIN YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, EDUCATIONAL OR SCIENTIFIC INSTITUTIONS, ASSOCIATIONS, INDIVIDUALS.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS AND PRESERVATION TO SELECT PARK CULTURAL RESOURCES RELATED TO THE ARCHIVAL RECORDS OF THE WOLF PROGRAM AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES. THESE RECORDS ARE IMPORTANT DOCUMENTARY RESOURCES THAT INFORM ONGOING ADMINISTRATIVE, LEGAL, SCIENTIFIC, AND CULTURAL PROJECTS. THESE MATERIALS ARE CURRENTLY THE MOST REQUESTED UNCATALOGUED RECORDS IN PARK ARCHIVES. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CATALOGING AND PRESERVATION TASKS SUCH AS CREATING DIGITAL SURROGATES OF LEGACY MEDIA NECESSARY FOR OPENING THE RECORDS TO STUDY AND USE. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, THE RECIPIENT WILL RECRUIT AND PLACE INDIVIDUALS TO ENGAGE IN PROCESSING, CATALOGING, AND PRESERVING RECORDS. PROCESSING WILL INCLUDE ARRANGING THE MATERIALS INTO LOGICAL GROUPINGS AND DESCRIBING THE RECORDS IN A NARRATIVE FINDING AID TO ASSIST WITH RESEARCHER ACCESS. CATALOGING REQUIRES ENTERING THE DESCRIPTIVE AND LOCATION DATA IN THE AGENCY COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM ICMS MCMS. PRESERVATION ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE REHOUSING IN ARCHIVAL FOLDERS, ENCAPSULATING FRAGILE ITEMS IN INERT MYLAR ENCLOSURES, AND DIGITIZING FRAGILE LEGACY MEDIA. PARTICIPANTS MAY ALSO ENGAGE IN TASKS RELATED TO REFERENCE REQUESTS AND ONSITE RESEARCHERS AND CONTRIBUTE TO OUTREACH EFFORTS RELATED TO SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND BEHIND-THE-SCENES TOURS TO ANNOUNCE THE OPENING OF THE COLLECTIONS. WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED UNDER THE TECHNICAL DIRECTION OF THE PARKS GS-11 ARCHIVIST. THE MUSEUM CATALOG RECORD PROVIDES ACCOUNTABILITY FOR AND PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS. BY CATALOGING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS, THIS PROJECT CREATES, PROMOTES, FACILITATES, AND IMPROVES THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF THE PARKS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND MAKES RECORDS ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. HISTORIANS, INTERPRETERS, WRITERS, AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC UTILIZE THE ARCHIVES TO INFORM PUBLISHED WORKS AND RESEARCH STUDIES, TO ILLUSTRATE PRESENTATIONS, AND IN OTHER PRODUCTS ACROSS MANY PLATFORMS, REACHING VAST AUDIENCES. HOWEVER, RECORDS THAT HAVE NOT BEEN CATALOGED CANNOT BE USED. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE VOLUME OF DOCUMENTS THAT ARE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC USE. THE WORK ALSO ENSURES THE ARCHIVAL RECORDS ARE PRESERVED FOR PERPETUITY.

THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NATIONALPARK SERVICE (NPS) EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTALRESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TOIMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. TO CARRYOUT AND FURTHER THIS STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITY, NPS IMPLEMENTS PROGRAMS THAT ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGEOF RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES BY UTILIZING PARK PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTOR SUPPORT ORCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. THIS TASK AGREEMENT FUNDS THE FIRST THREE OF FIVE ANNUAL REPORTS, ASSESSING THE BENEFITS AND IMPACT OF THE FEDERAL REHABILITATION TAX CREDIT IN FY 2023, FY 2024, AND FY 2025. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THEGENERAL PUBLIC.

THE GOAL OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO COMPLETE ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEYS AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR PUBLIC EDUCATION ABOUT CULTURAL RESOURCE ACTIVITIES IN GLEN CANYON NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE RECIPIENT WILL RECRUIT, HIRE, AND PLACE ONE INDIVIDUAL TO WORK AS A GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE (GBI) ARCHEOLOGICAL TECHNICIAN. THE GBI ARCHEOLOGICAL TECHNICIAN WILL PARTICIPATE IN ARCHEOLOGICAL FIELD WORK, CONTRIBUTE TO ARCHEOLOGICAL REPORTS, MAINTAIN ARCHEOLOGICAL DIGITAL AND SPATIAL DATA, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION TO BE USED IN PUBLIC AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS (INCLUDING SOCIAL MEDIA AND WEBSITE INFORMATION). THE PROJECT OUTCOME WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR PUBLIC EDUCATION ABOUT CULTURAL RESOURCE ACTIVITIES IN GLEN CANYON NATIONAL RECREATION AREA.THIS PROJECT ENGAGES RECIPIENTS, PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES, AND VISITORS IN SHARED CULTURAL RESOURCES STEWARDSHIP. THE PRODUCTS AND INFORMATION DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, AND PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATIONS CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL HERITAGE. THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY EXTERNAL TO THE NPS WILL ALSO GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED BY THE RESEARCH IN THIS PROJECT AND RELATED RESULTS DISSEMINATION.

THE GOAL OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CATALOG ARCHIVES THAT HAVE BEEN ACCESSIONED INTO GLACIER NATIONAL PARKS (GLAC) MUSEUM COLLECTION IN ORDER TO UPDATE AND MAKE COMPLETE GLACS MUSEUM CATALOG RECORDS IN THE NATIONAL CATALOG OF MUSEUM OBJECTS. THIS OBJECTIVE DIRECTLY TIERS FROM GUIDELINES STATED IN NPS-28: CULTURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES, CHAPTER 9, IN KEEPING WITH COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT P19AC00695. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE RECIPIENT WILL, THROUGH THEIR RESEARCH ASSOCIATE PROGRAM, RECRUIT AND PLACE A RESEARCH ASSOCIATE (RA) AT GLACIER NATIONAL PARK. THE RA WILL CATALOG (APPRAISE, ARRANGE, PROCESS, AND DESCRIBE) ARCHIVAL MATERIAL FOLLOWING NPS AND PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS FOR APPRAISAL, ARRANGEMENT, REHOUSING, AND DESCRIBING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS THAT ARE PRESERVED FOR PERPETUITY AND ACCURATELY CATALOGED, MAKING MORE ARCHIVAL MATERIAL ACCESSIBLE FOR RESEARCH USE.THE MUSEUM CATALOG RECORD PROVIDES ACCOUNTABILITY FOR AND PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL ACCESS TO MUSEUM OBJECTS. BY CATALOGING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS, THIS PROJECT CREATES, PROMOTES, FACILITATES, AND IMPROVES THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF THE PARKS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND MAKES RECORDS FROM GLACIER NATIONAL PARK ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. OVER 150 RESEARCHERS, ANNUALLY, ACCESS THE ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS AT GLACIER NATIONAL PARK. SELECT COLLECTIONS ARE SHARED ONLINE, EXPANDING THE PUBLIC USE OF THESE RESOURCES. HISTORIANS, INTERPRETERS, WRITERS, AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC UTILIZE THE ARCHIVES TO INFORM PUBLISHED WORKS AND RESEARCH STUDIES, TO ILLUSTRATE PRESENTATIONS, AND IN OTHER PRODUCTS ACROSS MANY PLATFORMS, REACHING VAST AUDIENCES. HOWEVER, RECORDS THAT HAVE NOT BEEN CATALOGED CANNOT BE USED. THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE VOLUME OF HISTORIC DOCUMENTS (ARCHIVES) THAT ARE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC USE THROUGH RESEARCH OR ONLINE. THE WORK ALSO ENSURES THE ARCHIVAL RECORDS ARE PRESERVED FOR PERPETUITY.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETAIL THE VARIOUS MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT HAVE OCCURRED AT PECOS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (PECO) FROM 1935-2022 TO HELP PARK MANAGERS, SCHOLARS, AND THE INTERESTED PUBLIC UNDERSTAND WHY THE PARK LOOKS AND OPERATES THE WAY THAT IT DOES, AND HOW PECO FITS INTO THE NPS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR INDIGENOUS LANDSCAPES. RESEARCH RESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER DIALOGUE AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE PRESERVATION OF A NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL AND HISTORIC PARK.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO WORK WITH PARTNERS TO COLLABORATIVELY CONDUCT HISTORIC RESEARCH. THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE A PROJECT HISTORIAN TO CONDUCT PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SOURCE RESEARCH, AND COMPLETE 15-20 ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PRODUCE A PEER REVIEWED MONOGRAPH LENGTH REPORT AND COMPLETE A TRANSFER OF KNOWLEDGE PRODUCT. THE PROJECT WILL HAVE TWO PARTS CONSISTING OF ORAL HISTORY AND ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY RESEARCH. RESEARCH RESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT MAY BE USED IN THE FUTURE TO DEVELOP PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES, AND EXPAND OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE FOR THE PUBLIC IN THE AREAS OF YOUTH ENGAGEMENT, INTERPRETATION, EDUCATION, AND VOLUNTEERISM.THIS AGREEMENT WILL EXPAND THE OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT IN THE AREAS OF INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION. THE HISTORICAL COMMUNITY EXTERNAL TO NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH RESEARCH AND RELATED RESULTS. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND OR IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL, CULTURAL, HISTORICAL, RECREATIONAL, AND OTHER ASPECTS OF PECOS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK.

PARTICIPANTS WILL GAIN VALUABLE EXPERIENCE AND CAREER DEVELOPMENT SKILLS IN THE FIELD OF MUSEUM AND ARCHIVES AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION OF SIGNIFICANT MUSEUM AND ARCHIVES RESOURCES. THE MUSEUM SPECIALIST WILL INVENTORY AND REHOUSE MUSEUM OBJECTS AND RECONCILE ARTIFACT LOCATIONS IN ICMS.  THE TEAM WILL IDENTIFY MISSING OR MISPLACED COLLECTIONS ITEMS, DECIPHER DOCUMENTATION, REHOUSE, AND DEVELOP ELECTRONIC CATALOG RECORDS. THEY WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE IN PROCESSING COLLECTIONS FROM START TO FINISH, PROVIDING ACCOUNTABILITY TO THE NPS MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND PREPARING IDENTIFIED COLLECTIONS FOR EVENTUAL RELOCATION TO THE REGION 1 HUB FACILITY.

THE YELLOWSTONE RESEARCH LIBRARY IS A VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR THE PUBLICNOT JUST LOCALLY BUT WORLDWIDE. THE LIBRARY CATALOG IS AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH A REGIONAL LIBRARY CONSORTIUM, WYLD, WHICH IS PART OF THE NATIONAL   INTERNATIONAL LIBRARY CATALOG, WORLDCAT. THIS PROJECT WILL DIGITIZE 1.5 LINEAR FEET (LF) OF SUPERINTENDENTS ANNUAL REPORTS DATING FROM 1872 TO PRESENT, 4.5 LF OF SUPERINTENDENTS MONTHLY REPORTS DATING FROM 1872 TO 1967, AND 1 LF OF NATURE NOTES DATING FROM 1924 TO 1958. THE DIGITAL COLLECTIONS WILL BE LOADED ONTO THE MONTANA MEMORY PROJECT, PARKS WEBSITE AND NPGALLERY  MAKING THEM ACCESSIBLE WORLDWIDE VIRTUALLY. THE WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY TWO LIBRARIANS HIRED THROUGH AN AGREEMENT WITH THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE. THEY WILL ALSO SERVE AS CONTACT TO THE PUBLIC WITH CASUAL INQUIRIES AND IN-DEPTH RESEARCH QUESTIONS. THE LIBRARIANS WILL CATALOG THE BACKLOG AND NEW MATERIALS MAKING THE MOST UP TO DATE RESEARCH AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE SUPPORT STAFF WILL SCAN THE LIBRARY, MUSEUM, AND ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS. THEY WILL ADD METADATA AND POST ONLINE FOR EASY ACCESS. THE STAFF WILL VERIFY AND QUALITY CONTROL ALL WORK BEFORE POSTING ONLINE. THE THREE MOST USED COLLECTIONS WILL BE DIGITIZED: 4.5 LINEAR FEET OF SUPERINTENDENTS MONTHLY REPORTS DATING FROM 1872 TO 1967 AND 1 LINEAR FEET OF NATURE NOTES DATING FROM 1924 TO 1958 WILL BE DIGITIZED FOR PUBLIC USE. THE COLLECTIONS WILL BE KEYWORD SEARCHABLE AND POSTED ON-LINE FOR PUBLIC ACCESS. THE STAFF WILL REDUCE BACKLOG THROUGH CATALOGING BOTH OLD AND NEW MATERIALS TO ENSURE THE MOST UP TO DATE RESEARCH IS AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC USE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY THE END OF THE APPOINTMENT, THE SUPPORT STAFF WILL POST COLLECTIONS ONLINE FOR GLOBAL USE.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PARKS MANAGEMENT STAFF AND SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS AS THEY WORK TO IMPROVE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE BASED ON HISTORIC EVENTS. THESE COLLECTIONS WILL BE FOUND IN PUBLICATIONS AND INFORMATION THROUGHOUT VARIOUS MEDIA AND PLATFORMS IN THE FUTURE.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMERGINGPROFESSIONALS TO WORK SIDE-BY-SIDE WITH NPS STAFF IN ACCOMPLISHING TASKS RELATED TOCULTURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT. SELECTED INDIVIDUALS WILL HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TOLEARN AND PARTICIPATE IN ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION OF MUSEUMCOLLECTIONS, AS OUTLINED IN NPS DIRECTOR'S ORDER 28, CULTURAL RESOURCEMANAGEMENT. PROJECT PARTICIPANTS WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE IN COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENTAND PRESERVATION THAT MAY INFORM CAREER GOALS AND DECISIONS AND WILL OTHERWISEENHANCE THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF NPS CULTURAL RESOURCE MANDATES AND HERITAGEPRESERVATION INITIATIVES.PROJECT OBJECTIVES -TO ACCOMPLISH THE PERFORMANCE GOALS PROJECT WORK WILL ADDRESS PREVENTATIVECONSERVATION NEEDS OF NPS MUSEUM COLLECTIONS STORED AT THE ALASKA REGIONALCURATORIAL CENTER (ARCC). PROJECT WORK WILL FOCUS ESPECIALLY ON OBJECT REHOUSINGAND CONDUCTING CONDITION STATUS UPDATES FOR NATURAL HISTORY AND ARCHAEOLOGYCOLLECTIONS. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THE PROJECT PERSONNEL TO GAINHANDS ON EXPERIENCE WORKING IN A PROFESSIONAL MUSEUM SETTING AND WILLSUBSTANTIALLY IMPROVE THE STABILITY AND LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF SIGNIFICANT NPSCOLLECTIONS FROM ALASKA.PUBLIC PURPOSE/BENEFICIERIES:THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE MASTER COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT'S INTENT OF EXPANDINGOPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WITH THE NPS TO ACCOMPLISH AGENCY GOALS OF CULTURALRESOURCES MANAGEMENT. THE COOPERATIVE APPROACH OF THE PROJECT ALLOWS PARTICIPANTS TOSERVE IN A DEVELOPMENTAL CAPACITY THAT DIRECTLY BENEFITS THEIR PROFESSIONAL GROWTH, ANDSUBSEQUENTLY CONTRIBUTE THEIR SKILLS TO THE BROADER CULTURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENTWORKFORCE. IN ADDITION TO THE PROJECT'S IMMEDIATE BENEFIT TO PARTICIPANTS, CARE ANDPRESERVATION OF MUSEUM COLLECTIONS IS PART OF THE NPS'S STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITY FORCULTURAL RESOURCES, WHICH IS ENTIRELY FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE LARGER PUBLIC. THIS PROJECT WILLSUPPORT ACTIVITIES INTENDED TO MAINTAIN NPS MUSEUM COLLECTIONS IN GOOD CONDITION SUCHTHAT THEY MAY CONTINUE TO BE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC USE AND ACCESS FOR GENERATIONS TO COME.

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THE SCOPE OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT ADDRESSES THE PRESERVATION AND ACCESS TO THE BETHLEHEM STEEL CORPORATION AND UNION IRON WORKS SHIPBUILDING DIVISION PLANS, HDC 345, SERIES 11 (SAFR 17494). OVER A PERIOD OF 4 YEARS, ARCHIVES SPECIALISTS AND TECHNICIANS WILL REHOUSE, DESCRIBE, PRESERVE, AND DIGITIZE THE PLANS AND DRAWINGS CURRENTLY HOUSED IN THE ORIGINAL UNION IRON WORKS/BETHLEHEM STEEL STORAGE TUBES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THERE ARE AN ESTIMATED 2,600 TUBES CONTAINING AS MANY AS 104,000 PLAN SHEETS AND INK ON LINEN DRAWINGS DATING FROM THE LATE 19TH THROUGH THE MID-20TH CENTURY. THE PROJECT IS PLANNED OVER A 4-YEAR PHASED PROJECT FUNDING. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GREATER ACCESS TO THE PUBLIC FOR THEIR BENEFIT AND ENJOYMENT OF AN IMPORTANT ARCHIVAL COLLECTION BY PROVIDING ENHANCED RESEARCH ACCESS, INTERPRETIVE DEPTH, AND EXHIBIT OPPORTUNITIES.THE PLANS AND DRAWINGS WILL BE CLEANED, REHOUSED, AND DESCRIBED IN BATCHES AT THE FILE LEVEL. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT MANY INDIVIDUAL DRAWINGS REQUIRE CONSERVATION. CONDITION REPORTS AND TREATMENT PLANS FOR AT-RISK MATERIAL WILL BE DRAFTED IN APPROPRIATE BATCHES; WHERE POSSIBLE, STABILIZATION AND TREATMENTS WILL BE PERFORMED AND DOCUMENTED IN-HOUSE. A SELECTION OF IN-SCOPE DRAWINGS WILL BE DIGITIZED AND DESCRIBED AT THE ITEM LEVEL FOR VIRTUAL ACCESS. SAFR ARCHIVISTS AND CURATORS WILL WORK WITH SFMNPA EMPLOYEES UNDERTAKING THE WORK IN PROJECT PLANNING, TECHNICAL OVERSIGHT, AND COMPLETION. SAFR WILL PROVIDE DIRECTION, WORKSPACE, AND EQUIPMENT. SFMNPA WILL HAVE ACCESS TO SECURE MUSEUM COLLECTION STORAGE, AND ALL PRESERVATION AND PROCESSING WORK WILL BE DONE ON SITE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:ASSIST NPS STAFF IN THE PROCESSING OF ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS INCLUDING THE ARRANGEMENT AND INVENTORY OF COLLECTIONS FROM THE SERIES TO ITEM LEVEL.PERFORM BASIC ARCHIVAL HOLDINGS MAINTENANCE OF COLLECTION HOLDINGS INCLUDING APPRAISAL, REHOUSING, LABELING, AND CREATING FOLDER LISTS.PROVIDE FOR STABILIZATION OF COLLECTIONS BY IDENTIFICATION OF MATERIALS REQUIRING REHOUSING AND MAKE IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING HOUSING. THIS WILL INCLUDE THE HUMIDIFICATION, FLATTENING, AND CLEANING OF ARCHIVAL COLLECTION AS APPROPRIATE.PREPARE COMPLETE ARCHIVAL RECORDS IN ICMS APPLYING SAFR LOCAL GUIDELINES, NPS REQUIREMENTS, AND OTHER PROFESSIONAL STANDARDS FOR DESCRIBING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS. PRODUCE FINDING AIDS AND/OR INDEXES FOR ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION.BENEFICIARIES:THE PARK IS MANDATED TO MAKE ITS COLLECTIONS OPEN, ACCESSIBLE, AND AVAILABLE TO EVERYONE. DUE TO THE CURRENT POOR STORAGE AND HOUSING OF THE COLLECTION, A VAST MAJORITY OF THE PLANS REMAIN INACCESSIBLE FOR PUBLIC ACCESS, RESEARCH, EXHIBITION, OR REPRODUCTION. ONCE THE PROJECT IS COMPLETED BY SFMNPA AND NPS, THE COLLECTION WILL BE REHOUSED, CONDITIONS DOCUMENTED, AND PLANS DESCRIBED AT THE FILE UNIT LEVEL RESULTING IN THE PARK BEING ABLE TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO THE PUBLIC FOR ITS BENEFIT AND ENJOYMENT

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK COOPERATIVELY TO PROVIDE SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS, EMERGING PROFESSIONALS, AND/OR RESEARCH ASSOCIATES (HEREAFTER REFERRED TO AS 'PARTICIPANTS') TO WORK SIDE-BY-SIDE WITH NPS PROFESSIONAL ARCHAEOLOGISTS TO OBTAIN EXPERIENCE IN COMPLEX ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ISSUES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:PARTICIPANTS WILL WORK AS PART OF A TEAM RESPONSIBLE FOR STEWARDSHIP AND MANAGEMENT OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES, AND WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE IN FIELDWORK, LABORATORY WORK, AND DATA MANAGEMENT.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THROUGH HANDS-ON PARTICIPATION, PARTICIPANTS WILL RECEIVE "REAL WORLD" EXPERIENCE WITH FEDERAL AGENCY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT WHILE COLLECTING RESOURCE DATA FOR THE PARK. PARTICIPANTS CAN USE THESE SKILL SETS TO ENTER AND/OR FURTHER THEIR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT CAREERS. A WRITTEN REPORT WILL SUMMARIZE PROJECT SUCCESSES AND CHALLENGES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE PROJECT SUCCESS.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND LONG TERM HUMAN USE PATTERNS WITHIN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK. THE NPS RECEIVES THE INDIRECT BENEFIT OF COMPLETING CULTURAL RESOURCE INVENTORY AS REQUIRED UNDER THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT. NEWLY ACQUIRED DATA WILL AID PARK PLANNING EFFORTS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION CRITICAL TO MAKING INFORMED TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: P22AC01216FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: THE GOALS OF THIS AGREEMENT ARE TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO PRODUCE STUDIES OUTLINED IN NPS-28: CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GUIDELINE. THESE STUDIES SUPPORT THE NPS'S MISSION TO PRESERVE AND INTERPRET CULTURAL RESOURCES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THIS, AND FUTURE, GENERATIONS.REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THIS AWARD SUPPORTS THE UPDATE OF NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES (NRHP) DOCUMENTATION FOR RICHMOND NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD PARK, INCLUDING REVIEW BY THE VIRGINIA STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE AND SIGNATURE OF THE KEEPER. NRHP NOMINATIONS EVALUATE AND DESCRIBE ALL RESOURCES, REGARDLESS OF OWNERSHIP, WITHIN THE AUTHORIZED BOUNDARY OF THE PARK (INCLUDING ARCHEOLOGY) AND DISTINGUISH BETWEEN CONTRIBUTING AND NON-CONTRIBUTING RESOURCES WITHIN THE DISTRICT. RICHMOND NBP HAS ACQUIRED APPROXIMATELY 1000 ACRES OF NEW PARK LANDS THAT NEED TO BE EVALUATED; COMPLETED NRHP DOCUMENTATION IS REQUIRED FOR ALL HISTORICAL UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE NATIONAL REGISTER DOCUMENTATION FOR RESOURCES WITHIN THE AUTHORIZED BOUNDARY OF RICHMOND NBP IN ACCORDANCE WITH CURRENT STANDARDS AND SCHOLARSHIP. THE PARK HAS ACQUIRED APPROXIMATELY 1000 ACRES SINCE 2018, WHEN THE LAST PARK-WIDE, COMPREHENSIVE DOCUMENTATION WAS PREPARED, AND THE NOMINATION MUST BE UPDATED TO ACCOUNT FOR THESE NEW LANDS. THE NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION WILL 1) FOLLOW THE FORMAT OF NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION FORM, 2) INCLUDE A NARRATIVE STATEMENT OF SIGNIFICANCE, 3) A NARRATIVE DESCRIPTION OF RESOURCES, AND 4) A LIST OF CONTRIBUTING AND NON-CONTRIBUTING RESOURCES. TWO DRAFTS FOR REVIEW BY NPS STAFF AND PARTNERS WILL BE PREPARED. A THIRD AND FINAL DRAFT WILL BE PREPARED FOR REVIEW BY THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER AND THE FEDERAL PRESERVATION OFFICER. THE COMPLETED NATIONAL REGISTER NOMINATION WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR THE PUBLIC TO READ AND DOWNLOAD FROM NPS.GOV SITES AS WELL AS ON FILE AT THE STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS UPDATED NRHP NOMINATION WILL TAKE NO MORE THAN 18 MONTHS TO COMPLETE, AND WILL RESULT IN AN APPROVED NOMINATION AND LISTING IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES FOR RICHMOND NBP THAT INCLUDES ALL PARK PROPERTY. THE NOMINATION WILL SUPPORT RESOURCE PRESERVATION AND INTERPRETATION AT THE PARK; A DIGITAL COPY WILL ALSO BE AVAILABLE FOR DOWNLOAD FROM THE NRHP DATABASE. BENEFICIARIES: THIS NOMINATION WILL DOCUMENT THE RESOURCES WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF RICHMOND NBP, AND WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, PLANS, AND OPERATIONS ABOUT THE PRESERVATION AND INTERPRETATION OF PARK AND PARTNER RESOURCES, PARTICULARLY PLANS FOR THE NEWLY ACQUIRED ACRES. IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH A GREATER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF RICHMOND'S HISTORY AND SIGNIFICANCE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE NPS AND THE RECIPIENT WISH TO COOPERATE IN PROGRAMS AND STUDIES IN SUPPORT OF ARCHIVES USE AND ACCESS THAT ENHANCES PUBLIC APPRECIATION, UNDERSTANDING AND STEWARDSHIP OF MANY OF OUR NATION'S MOST TREASURED LANDSCAPES AND THE FUNDAMENTAL AND ASSOCIATED RESOURCES AND VALUES ASSOCIATED WITH OLMSTED NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO FURTHER REFINE AND DEVELOP A DIGITIZATION PROGRAM FOR PORTIONS OF THE OLMSTED ARCHIVAL COLLECTION. SPECIFICALLY, THE NPS AND THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK TOGETHER TO SCAN SELECT ITEMS FROM THE ARCHIVES TO BE DIGITIZED USING BOTH IN-HOUSE EQUIPMENT AND OFF-SITE THROUGH A VENDOR, AS NEEDED. THE RESULTING SCANS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL DRAMATICALLY INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THIS NATIONAL RESOURCE, WHILE DECREASING THE NEED TO CONTINUOUSLY HANDLE FRAGILE HISTORIC DOCUMENTS, THUS PRESERVING THEM UNIMPAIRED. THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO ENGAGE A PROJECT CONSULTANT WHO WILL WORK WITH NPS STAFF TO REVIEW EXISTING DIGITIZING PRACTICES AND PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR KEY TECHNICAL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT SUCH AS METADATA CAPTURE AND THE USE OF A DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (DAMS). THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CLEAR EXAMPLES OF "BEST PRACTICE" FOR FUTURE DIGITIZATION WORK.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY JULY 2024, ADDITIONAL IMAGES OF IMPORTANT ARCHIVAL DOCUMENTS WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. WORKING WITH THE RECIPIENT, TEAM WILL HAVE STABLISHED BEST PRACTICES FOR DIGITIZING OF LARGE FORMAT DOCUMENTS. THESE BEST PRACTICES WILL HELP OTHER REPOSITORIES AND NPS COLLECTIONS WHEN PLANNING FOR LARGESCALE DIGITAL PROJECTS.BENEFICIARIES:THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE OUR RESEARCHERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO WILL GAIN WIDER ACCESS TO THE ARCHIVAL MATERIALS TO FURTHER THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE OLMSTED LEGACY WORLDWIDE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):CLIMATE CHANGE POSES AN UNPRECEDENT THREAT TO OUR PLANET, INCLUDING THE CULTURAL RESOURCES THAT FALL UNDER THE MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS). PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE PARK HISTORIC STRUCTURE AND CULTURAL LANDSCAPES PROGRAM IN PROFESSIONAL PROCEDURE GUIDANCE. SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THE NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICES (NCSHPO) WILL ASSIST THE PARK HISTORIC STRUCTURES AND CULTURAL LANDSCAPES PROGRAM (PHSCLP) BY PROVIDING SUPPORT IN THE CREATION OF TWO PROFESSIONAL PROCEDURE GUIDES. A DIGITAL CONTENT COORDINATOR AND PROCEDURE GUIDE PREPARER WILL COMPLETE THE PROJECT. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DIGITAL CONTENT COORDINATOR: PROVIDE DIGITAL CONTENT COORDINATION SERVICES TO PROGRAMS. SUPPORT IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A CRPS DIGITAL CONTENT STRATEGY; TRACK CORE BASELINE DOCUMENT COLLECTIONS DIGITAL CONTENT CREATIONTECHNICAL EXPERTISE ON COMPLIANCE WITH SECTION 508 TRAVEL TO PARKS/TRAINING WORKSHOPS/FIELD VENUES TO VIDEO- AND PHOTO-DOCUMENT PROCEEDINGS IN SUPPORT OF PUBLIC OUTREACH MATERIALS. PROCEDURE GUIDE PREPARER: PREPARE TWO GUIDES TO STANDARDIZE NPS STAFF INVOLVED IN DATA ENTRY OR EDITING RECORDS IN DATABASES. PREPARATION OF THE PROFESSIONAL PROCEDURES GUIDE (PPG) IN COLLABORATION WITH THE REGIONAL COORDINATORS. PREPARATION OF THE PPG IN COLLABORATION WITH THE REGIONAL COORDINATORS. COORDINATION OF REVIEW PROCESSES OF DRAFT PPGS BY VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING REGIONAL CRIS-HS AND CL COORDINATORS AND PROGRAM MANAGERS. DESKTOP PUBLISHING OF EACH PPG AS AN INTERACTIVE, 508-COMPLIANT PDFS FOR ONLINE DISTRIBUTION TO THE FIELD. ATTEND A COORDINATORS WORKSHOPS TO RESOLVE ISSUES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A NEW ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY, BRINGING TO LIGHT THE MANY AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES DONE BY THE UNITED STATES ARMY, THE NPS, AND CONCESSIONERS BETWEEN 1905-1965. THE INDIVIDUAL HIRED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT ORAL HISTORIES OF FORMER STAFF MEMBERS WHO MANAGED THE PARK'S AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, CONDUCT FIELD WORK TO DOCUMENT ON-THE-GROUND EVIDENCE OF PAST AGRICULTURAL IMPACTS ON THE LANDSCAPE, AND USE SATELLITE IMAGERY AND PERIOD PHOTOGRAPHS TO DETERMINE THE SCOPE OF THESE PRACTICES. ONE OF THE MAIN QUESTIONS THAT THIS HISTORY HOPES TO ANSWER IS WHERE AND WHAT CROPS WERE PLANTED, ANIMALS WERE FED, AND LIVESTOCK PASTURED. ONCE THIS INFORMATION IS DETERMINED, THE PARK'S GIS DATA WILL BE UPDATED TO IDENTIFY CULTIVATION AREAS WITHIN THE PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:A HISTORIAN WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH, FIELD SURVEYS, AND ORAL HISTORIES TO CREATE AN ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY AND A DRAFT ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY THAT DETERMINES WHERE/WHAT CROPS WERE PLANTED IN YELLOWSTONE, AND WHERE/WHAT ANIMALS WERE GRAZED IN THE PARK. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY THE END OF THE APPOINTMENT, THE HISTORIAN WILL PROVIDE AN ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY AND DRAFT ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY AS WELL AS WORKED WITH GIS PROFESSIONALS TO UPDATE THE PARK'S MAPS.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PARK'S MANAGEMENT STAFF AND SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS AS THEY WORK TO MANAGE YELLOWSTONE'S LANDSCAPE IN THE FACE OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PUBLIC WILL BE MADE AWARE OF THIS RELATIVELY UNKNOWN ASPECT OF YELLOWSTONE'S HISTORY.

SUMMARY OF PROJECT-SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: SUPPORT FOR CULTURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT AT ZION NATIONAL PARK; SPECIFICALLY, COMPLIANCE PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, HISTORIC RESEARCH, CULTURAL INVENTORIES AND FIELD METHODS, MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS, HISTORIC STRUCTURE DOCUMENTATION AND PRESERVATION, AND SUMMARY REPORTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THROUGH THIS AGREEMENT GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE MEMBERS WILL RECEIVE HANDS-ON TRAINING IN CULTURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT IN NATIONAL PARKS, INCLUDING CONDUCTING HISTORIC RESEARCH, SMALL SCALE CULTURAL INVENTORIES AND SURVEY, PREPARING COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION, REPORT WRITING, AND DEVELOPING HISTORIC STRUCTURE DOCUMENTATION AND PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES. THE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC SERVICE AND YOUTH EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING IN PRESERVATION RELATED WORK. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF REPORTS AND MATERIALS TO SUCCESSFULLY UNDERSTAND AND PARTICIPATE IN THE MANAGEMENT OF CULTURAL RESOURCES THROUGH ACTIONS REQUIRED BY THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT OF 1966.BENEFICIARIES: BECAUSE THE PROJECTS INVOLVING CULTURAL RESOURCES ARE IN SUCH VISIBLE AND HIGH-VISITATION AREAS, BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE VISITORS TO ZION NP (EXCEEDING 5 MILLION PEOPLE ANNUALLY), ZION NP MANAGERS, AND THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE MEMBERS THEMSELVES, WHO RECEIVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN NEW SKILLS, INTERACT WITH PEOPLE FROM ACROSS THE GLOBE, AND EXPERIENCE LAND-MANAGEMENT EFFORTS AND PROJECT COMPLETION.

CULTURAL RESOURCES STEWARDSHIP IN YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK

PERFORMANCE GOALS -THIS PROJECT ENGAGES YOUNG ADULTS AS ARCHEOLOGICAL TECHNICIANS AT JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK TO ASSIST WITH ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEY, MONITORING, SITE RECORDING, DOCUMENTATION, AND REPORTING FOR ARCHEOLOGICAL ACTIVITIES UNDER THE DIRECTION AND OVERSIGHT OF NPS PROFESSIONAL ARCHEOLOGISTS. THE ARCHEOLOGY PROGRAM AT JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK REGULARLY CONDUCTS ACTIVITIES PURSUANT TO WHAT ARE COMMONLY REFERRED TO AS SECTIONS 106 AND 110 OF THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT (FORMERLY 16 U.S.C. 470 ET SEQ.; NOW 54 U.S.C. 300101) AND GENERALLY KNOWN AS COMPLIANCE AND INVENTORY, RESPECTIVELY. THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENTAL EXPERIENCE TO YOUNG ADULTS BY HAVING THEM ASSIST THE PARK WITH COMPLIANCE RELATED CLEARANCE SURVEYS AND ASSESSMENTS, AND INVENTORY SURVEYS TO DOCUMENT AND RECORD ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES IN PREVIOUSLY UNSTUDIED AREAS OF THE PARK. THE RECIPIENT, GBI, WILL RECRUIT YOUNG ADULTS WHO WILL WORK ALONGSIDE NPS PROFESSIONAL ARCHEOLOGISTS AND ARCHEOLOGICAL TECHNICIANS TO HELP THE PARK MEET ITS RESPONSIBILITIES UNDER THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT.2. PROJECT OBJECTIVES -PERSONNEL FROM GBI AND NPS WILL COLLABORATE TO RECRUIT ARCHEOLOGICAL TECHNICIANS WHO CAN ASSIST THE PARK IN CONDUCTING ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEY, SECTION 106 COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION, SECTION 110 PROACTIVE ARCHAEOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT, SITE RECORDING, DOCUMENTATION, REPORT WRITING, AND GIS DATA ENTRY AND DATA MANAGEMENT. THE RESULTS OF ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO HELP ENHANCE RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ROCK CLIMBING AND STREAMLINE COMPLIANCE ON DEFERRED MAINTENANCE PROJECTS.THE RESULT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEYS OF:RECREATIONAL ROCK-CLIMBING AREAS, INCLUDING TRADITIONAL, SPORT, AND BOULDERING AREAS, TO ENHANCE AND IMPROVE OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES;AREAS OF POTENTIAL EFFECT (APES) FOR DEFERRED MAINTENANCE PROJECTS FOCUSED ON DETERIORATING INFRASTRUCTURE AND TRAILS;REFUGIA FOR JOSHUA TREES AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN TO THE PARK;PROPOSED BACKCOUNTRY CAMPING LOCATIONS;RYAN RANCH HISTORIC SITETHIS BENEFITS THE VISITORS AT JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG PEOPLE TO LEARN ABOUT NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP AND PRESERVATION BY SPENDING TIME WORKING ON PROJECTS WITH NATIONAL PARK SERVICE RESOURCES MANAGERS, SUCH AS PERFORMING CONSERVATION TREATMENTS, COMPLETING RESEARCH RELATED TO MUSEUM COLLECTIONS, AND DEVELOPING AND MAINTAINING INTERPRETIVE EXHIBITS. THE INDIVIDUALS PARTICIPATING IN THE PROJECT WILL GAIN PROFESSIONAL TRAINING, EDUCATION, AND EXPERIENCE THROUGH PROJECT WORK AND IN INTERACTION WITH NATIONAL PARK SERVICE RESOURCE MANAGERS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:YOUTH WILL HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN AND PARTICIPATE IN PARK OPERATIONAL AREAS INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO: MUSEUM PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THESE YOUNG ADULTS WILL BE UPGRADING STORAGE AND HOUSING FOR OVER 15,000 NATURAL HISTORY SPECIMENS TO MEET NATIONAL PARK SERVICE MUSEUM STANDARDS, GAINING EXPERIENCE WITH THE INTERIOR COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM CATALOGING DATABASE, EXHIBIT INSTALLATION AND PERFORMING OTHER PREVENTIVE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD BY PARTICIPANTS LIVING AND WORKING AT YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK. PARTICIPANTS WILL UPGRADE STORAGE AND HOUSING FOR OVER 15,000 NATURAL HISTORY SPECIMENS. WET SPECIMENS AND ENTOMOLOGY WILL BE TARGETED THE FIRST YEAR, AND THE HERBARIUM COLLECTION WILL BE COMPLETED IN THE SECOND YEAR.THIS PROJECT BENEFITS BOTH THE MUSEUM SUPPORT TECHNIIAN AND THE FUTURE VISITING PUBLIC TO THIS MUSEUM COLLECTION.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THIS AWARD SUPPORTS THE COMPLETION OF A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY FOR COLTSVILLE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY IS A REQUIRED BASELINE DOCUMENT THAT PROVIDES A HISTORICAL OVERVIEW OF A PARK OR REGION AND IDENTIFIES A PARK'S CULTURAL RESOURCES WITHIN HISTORIC CONTEXTS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THE RESEARCHER WILL DOCUMENT, ANALYZE, AND CONTEXTUALIZE COLTSVILLE'S RESOURCES IN LIGHT OF NEW SCHOLARSHIP AND PERSPECTIVES. THE STUDY WILL BE CHRONOLOGICAL, AND WILL CONNECT THE SPECIFIC ARCHITECTURE, LANDSCAPE, AND RESOURCES OF THE COLTSVILLE SITE WITH BROADER, RELATED THEMES IN UNITED STATES HISTORY, INCLUDING LABOR, IMMIGRATION, INDUSTRIALIZATION, AND WESTWARD EXPANSION. THE STUDY WILL FOCUS ON RESOURCES WITHIN THE PARK BOUNDARY, BUT THE ANALYSIS MAY ALSO REFERENCE RELATED PROPERTIES TO FRAME CONTEXTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS HRS WILL TAKE APPROXIMATELY 2 YEARS TO COMPLETE, AND WILL RESULT IN A WRITTEN REPORT FOR USE BY THE NPS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE HISTORY OF COLTSVILLE AND ITS RESOURCES. IT WILL AID IN THE CREATION OF INTERPRETIVE MEDIA AND INFORM PARK PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT.BENEFICIARIES: THIS HRS WILL PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH A GREATER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF COLTSVILLE'S HISTORY AND SIGNIFICANCE. IT WILL BE USED BY NPS STAFF TO DEVELOP INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION PLANS AND PROGRAMS, TO DEVELOP PRINTED AND DIGITAL CONTENT ABOUT THE HISTORY OF THE PARK FOR INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL AUDIENCES, AND TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, PLANS, AND OPERATIONS.

OBJECTIVES:PRODUCETHREE MAINSTAGE THEATRICAL PRODUCTIONS;PROVIDE STUDENT MATINEES, GUIDEDANDVIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS, ORATORY PROGRAMS, PODCAST PROGRAMS,TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT.LIVE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIP:FOR STUDENTSWHOAREUNABLE TO VISIT THE THEATRE IN PERSONSTUDENT MATINEES:FREE TICKETS FOR FORD'S THEATRE MAINSTAGE PRODUCTIONS TO LOCALSTUDENTSLINCOLN ORATORY FESTIVAL:LOCALGRADES 3-8, TO EXPERIENCE HOW THE POWER OF PUBLIC SPEAKINGLINCOLN ONLINE ORATORY PROJECT:A CONDENSED VERSION OF LOCAL PROGRAMSTAND UP, BE HEARD: THE PODCAST,HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS CREATED PODCAST EPISODESONE DESTINY (IN-PERSON AND STREAMING): ONE-ACT PLAYABOUTLINCOLN'S ASSASSINATION.BENEFICIARIES:60,000 AUDIENCE MEMBERS75,000 LOCALANDNATIONAL STUDENTS AND TEACHER.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THE TASK AGREEMENT WILL DEVELOP PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES THAT WILL RESULT IN EXPANDING THE OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT IN THE AREAS OF HISTORY, INTERPRETATION, EDUCATION, AND VOLUNTEERISM. THE PURPOSE OF THIS UNDERTAKING IS TO FOSTER THE PUBLIC'S APPRECIATION FOR THE WORLD WAR II HOME FRONT PERIOD THROUGH MULTIGENERATIONAL HERITAGE EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES. VISITORS (ONLINE AND IN PERSON) AND EDUCATORS WILL GAIN AN ENHANCED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE WAR IMPACTED ALL AMERICANS ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND HOW HISTORIC PLACES REPRESENT BOTH SHARED AND INDIVIDUAL STORIES ABOUT THE PERIOD AND ITS LEGACY. EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS WILL HAVE EXPANDED OPPORTUNITIES FOR TEACHING AND LEARNING ABOUT THE SAME. PERFORMANCE GOALS - THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE AMERICAN WORLD WAR II HERITAGE CITY PROGRAM MANDATED IN SECTION 9007 OF THE JOHN D. DINGELL, JR. CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECREATION ACT OF 2019 (P.L. 116-9). PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESEARCH AND DEVELOP HERITAGE TRAVEL AND EDUCATIONAL PRODUCTS TO HIGHLIGHT HISTORIC RESOURCES RELATED TO THE WORLD WAR II HOME FRONT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT WITH THE NATIONAL TRUST FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION IS TO CREATE HIGH LEVEL EDUCATIONAL CLASSROOM PROGRAMMING THAT SUPPORT THE STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL PARTNERS OF NPS' CRPS PROGRAM. SPECIFICALLY, NPS WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NTHP TO EXECUTE CLASSROOM SESSIONS THAT WILL BUILD CAPACITY AND INCLUSIVENESS IN THE PRESERVATION FIELD. ADDITIONALLY, THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT NPS' PARTNERS PARTICIPATION IN THESE TRAININGS AND THIS CONFERENCE WHILE HELPING NPS TO DEVELOP EDUCATION SESSIONS FOCUSED SPECIFICALLY ON PARTNER NEEDS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO SHOWCASE SUCCESSFUL PUBLIC AND PRIVATE INVESTMENT AND PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL PRESERVATION PRACTITIONERS. THE PARTICIPANTS IN THESE SESSIONS WILL SEE HOW NPS IS WORKING TO IMPROVE THE PROGRAMMATIC INFRASTRUCTURE OF NOT ONLY NPS MANAGED PROPERTIES BUT PRIVATELY-OWNED HISTORIC PROPERTIES. THIS KNOWLEDGE CAN BE USED IN PROPERTIES AND PROJECTS AROUND THE COUNTRY. ADDITIONALLY, THE EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS BEING DEVELOPED WILL ALLOW OUR PARTNERS AN OPPORTUNITY TO WORK ON A RANGE OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION TOPICS THEY ARE FACING TO IMPROVE THEIR OWN PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND SUPPORT TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. LASTLY, THE FUNDING TO SUPPORT DIVERSE PARTICIPATION WILL ENSURE THEY ARE AN ACTIVE AND EQUAL PARTNER IN THESE EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS AND CONVERSATIONS.

CREATE AND MANAGE FIELD DATA COLLECTION APPLICATIONSUTILIZE GIS SOFTWARE TO ANALYZE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF PARK PROJECTSCREATE MAPS THAT VISUALIZE THE ANALYSIS AND DATAPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DOCUMENTS PROJECT DATA AND ENSURES THE DATA AND DOCUMENTATION ARE STORED APPROPRIATELYMAPPING AND DATA DECISIONS ARE CLEARLY DOCUMENTEDDATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS TOOLS MEET PARK DECISION-MAKING NEEDS AND WITHSTAND EXTERNAL REVIEWBENEFICIARIES:THE OUTCOMES DESCRIBED WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF FORMATS WITH THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA'S HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE, EDUCATION AND INTERPRETATION STAKEHOLDERS, THUS PRESERVING THE INFORMATION FOR THE PUBLIC AND TRIBAL GROUPS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREPARE A WHISKEYTOWN NATIONAL RECREATION AREA ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY, A BASELINE DOCUMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL PREPARE THE ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY OF THE PARK FROM ITS ORIGINS TO THE PRESENT IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND HOW THE PARK UNIT WAS CONCEIVED, ESTABLISHED, AND HOW IT HAS BEEN ADMINISTERED OVER THE PAST 50-PLUS YEARS.THE COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP A RESEARCH PLAN AND SCHEDULE; CONDUCT SITE VISITS AND GATHER ARCHIVAL RESEARCH; SUBMIT A DETAILED OUTLINE OF THE HISTORY; SUBMIT A DRAFT, REVISED, FINAL, AND COMPLETE DRAFT OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY; AND PRESENT FINDINGS FROM THE REPORT TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH PRESENTATIONS OR DIGITAL MEDIA. THE ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC, RESEARCHERS, AND WHISKEYTOWN STAFF, INCREASING THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE PARK AND ITS HISTORICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE HERITAGE. NEW CONTRIBUTIONS TO KNOWLEDGE OF THE HISTORY OF WHISKEYTOWN NATIONAL RECREATION AREA WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR PARK INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS AND WEBSITE CONTENT, BRINGING A FULLER UNDERSTANDING OF THE PARK'S HISTORY AND SIGNIFICANCE TO THE PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT A CREW OF CAVE SPECIALISTS WHO WILL VISIT, SURVEY, MAP, PHOTOGRAPH, AND INVENTORY UP TO 30 NPS-MANAGED CAVES TO EVALUATE BIOLOGICAL, GEOLOGICAL, ARCHAEOLOGICAL, AND PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES. THEY WILL REPORT ON THEIR AREAS OF EXPERTISE TO HELP THE NPS MANAGE THE CAVES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:REPORT WITH DETAILED PALEONTOLOGICAL, ARCHEOLOGICAL, BIOLOGICAL, HYDROLOGICAL, AND GEOLOGICAL INFORMATION FOR UP TO 30 NPS-MANAGED CAVES IN THE SOUTH SNAKE RANGE MAPS, INVENTORIES, AND HIGH-QUALITY PHOTOS FOR UP TO 30 NPS-MANAGED CAVES UP TO TWO PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ABOUT THE CAVES OF WHITE PINE COUNTY TO SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY GROUPS AND NEWSPAPERS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR INTERPRETIVE SIGNS AT UP TO 5 CAVESENGAGE LOCAL VOLUNTEERS AND CAVE GROUPS WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO ASSIST IN PROJECTPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:HIRE CAVE SPECIALIST MAY 2022, CAVE SPECIALIST START, TRAINING AND ORIENTATION, PLAN FIELD SEASSON JUNE 2022, START CAVE VISITS THRU OCT. 2022, REPOTS, MAPS, PHOTOS FEB. THRU OCT. 2023.BENEFICIARIES: VISITORS TO GREAT BASIN NATIONAL PARK AND THE AMERICAN PEOPLE

PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO CREATE AN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM TO BRING MORE AFRICAN AMERICAN YOUNG PROFESSIONALS INTO HISTORIC PRESERVATION, AND RELATED CAREER FIELDS, SUCH AS ARCHITECTURE, ENGINEERING, URBAN AND REGIONAL PLANNING, CONSTRUCTION SCIENCE AND HISTORY, AND RAISE AWARENESS OF THE CULTURAL LEGACY OF HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES (HBCUS). THE FUNDING PROVIDED WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT HOPE CREW PROJECTS FOR SELECT STUDENTS FROM MORGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY, AND HAMPTON UNIVERSITY. PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BRING MORE AFRICAN AMERICAN YOUNG PROFESSIONALS INTO HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND RAISE AWARENESS OF THE CULTURAL LEGACY OF HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES (HBCUS). THE PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION AMONG THE NATIONAL TRUST FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION'S HANDS ON PRESERVATION EXPERIENCE (HOPE) CREW, MORGAN STATE UNIVERSITY (MSU), THE WESTERN CENTER FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION (WCHP) (UNDER THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE), AND THE WHITE HOUSE INITIATIVE ON HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES (HBCU). THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A PROFESSIONAL NETWORK THROUGH HANDS ON EXPERIENCE, MENTORING, AND ONLINE MODULES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE TWO RESEARCH ASSOCIATES WITH TRAINING IN PROFESSIONAL ARCHIVAL STANDARDS, PRINCIPLES, AND PROCEDURES. THE RESEARCH ASSOCIATES WITH RECEIVE HANDS-ON APPRAISAL, DESCRIBING, CATALOGING AND PRESERVATION TRAINING THROUGH APPLIED PROCESSES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF FINDING AIDS USING THE INTERIOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (ICMS). PRESENTATIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATIONS AND TO PROMOTE NPS RECORDS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF ARRANGING AND DESCRIBING TWO RECENT GIFTS TO THE MAGGIE L. WALKER NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE WHICH ADD TO THE INDEPENDENT ORDER OF ST. LUKE (IOSL) RECORDS AND TO THE MAGGIE L. WALKER FAMILY PAPERS AND THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT RECORDS OF FREDERICKSBURG & SPOTSYLVANIA NATIONAL MILITARY PARK. THESE PROJECTS WILL ENSURE PROPER PRESERVATION OF THE RECORDS ACCORDING TO NATIONAL PARK SERVICE STANDARDS AND FACILITATE EASIER ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS BY RESEARCHERS. THE PROJECT FOCUSES ON PROVIDING PRACTICAL, PROJECT-BASED LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT WILL BE SPECIFICALLY USEFUL FOR RECENT GRADUATE STUDENTS WHO WISH TO PURSUE A CAREER FOCUSED ON MANAGING ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:RESEARCH ASSOCIATE, ARCHIVIST I, FULLTIMECATALOGS FREDERICKSBURG & SPOTSYLVANIA NATIONAL MILITARY PARK PERMANENT RECORDS. DUTIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A PROCESSING PLAN, EVALUATING CONSERVATION NEEDS, FILE ARRANGEMENT, ENTERING DATA INTO COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, REHOUSING COLLECTION MATERIALS, AND WRITING A FINDING AID. ADDITIONAL DUTIES INCLUDE ASSISTING IN OTHER CATALOGING AND INVENTORY PROJECTS AS ASSIGNED. ARCHIVIST I WILL TRAVEL WITH NMSC LEAD ARCHIVIST, TO IDENTIFY AND PICK UP ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS FOR PROCESSING AND RETURN THEM TO THE PARK ONCE THE PROJECT IS COMPLETE.RESEARCH ASSOCIATE, ARCHIVIST II, PARTTIMEASSISTING IN ARRANGING AND DESCRIBING APPROXIMATELY FORTY-TWO LINEAR FEET OF PAPERS AND RECORDS NEWLY ACQUIRED BY MAGGIE L. WALKER HISTORIC SITE; ENTERING DATA INTO COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DATABASE; PROVIDING REHOUSING AND OTHER CONSERVATION ACTIONS; PUBLICIZING COLLECTIONS THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AND SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS.BENEFICIARIES:THE PUBLIC AND RESEARCHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM ACCESS FOR THE FIRST TIME TO BOTH THE MAGGIE L WALKER PAPERS AND HER BUSINESS RECORDS. AS A LEADER HER SUCCESSES AND VISION OFFERED TANGIBLE IMPROVEMENTS IN THE WAY OF LIFE FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS AND WOMEN.THE PUBLIC AND RESEARCHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM ACCESS TO THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT RECORDS OF FREDERICKSBURG & SPOTSYLVANIA NATIONAL MILITARY PARK. THESE RECORDS PROVIDE BASELINE DOCUMENTATION FOR UPCOMING ADMINISTRATIVE AND CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS AND WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR REFERENCE AND RESEARCH FOR PUBLIC ACCESS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: P-P-NPSA-22-031PURPOSE OF AWARD:THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO PROVIDE DIRECT ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORTING NPS' PARTNERS ATTENDANCE AND PARTICIPATION IN HIGH LEVEL EDUCATIONAL FIELD SESSIONS AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING THAT SUPPORT THE STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL PARTNERS OF NPS' CRPS PROGRAM. SPECIFICALLY, NPS WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF DENVER TO EXECUTE TRAINING SESSIONS THAT WILL BUILD CAPACITY IN THE FIELD FOCUSING ON THE SUBJECT OF REPATRIATION OF NATIVE AMERICAN CULTURAL ITEMS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE FIELD SESSIONS, EDUCATIONAL SESSION, AND PARTNER SCHOLARSHIPS WILL BE DELIVERED FOR THE 8TH ANNUAL REPATRIATION VIRTUAL CONFERENCE, OCTOBER 11, 12, AND 13, 2022. THE CONFERENCE ANNUALLY ATTRACTS ROUGHLY 500-700 PARTICIPANTS FROM ACROSS THE COUNTRY. ATTENDEES REPRESENT PROFESSIONALS IN THE FIELD OF REPATRIATION AT THE FEDERAL, STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT, AS WELL AS THE PRIVATE SECTOR.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO SHOWCASE SUCCESSFUL REPATRIATION PROJECTS AND PARTNERSHIPS. THE PARTICIPANTS IN THESE SESSIONS WILL SEE HOW NPS IS WORKING TO IMPROVE THE COMPLIANCE PROCESS REQUIRED BY FEDERAL LAW, AND THIS KNOWLEDGE CAN BE USED IN REPATRIATION PROJECTS AROUND THE COUNTRY.BENEFICIARIES: CONFERENCE ATTENDEES

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE NEW SCHOLARSHIP ABOUT THE HISTORY OF THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD TO THE PUBLIC IN A FORMAT THAT IS PARTICULARLY ENGAGING FOR YOUNG, DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THE "QUESTIONING CONVERSATIONS" VIDEO SERIES WILL:EXPAND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD AND THE NEWEST TRENDS IN HISTORICAL SCHOLARSHIP.ENGAGE A YOUNG AND DIVERSE AUDIENCE WITH THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD AND THE CRAFT OF HISTORY.INSPIRE THE NEXT GENERATION OF DIVERSE STEWARDS ENGAGED IN FREEDOM DIALOG, LEARNING TOLERANCE, AND HERITAGE PRESERVATION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE RECIPIENT WILL SCHEDULE AND COORDINATE FOUR INTERVIEWS BETWEEN WELL-KNOWN FIGURES IN POPULAR CULTURE AND HISTORIANS ABOUT TOPICS RELATED TO THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD. THESE CONVERSATIONS WILL BE RECORDED, AND THE RECORDINGS EDITED FOR LENGTH AND CLARITY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A SERIES OF FOUR VIDEOS FOR POSTING TO A NPS WEBSITE BY THE END OF 2023.BENEFICIARIES:THE VIDEOS WILL BE AVAILABLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH THE NPS WEBSITE AND SOCIAL MEDIA. THE SERIES IS PARTICULARLY TARGETED TOWARD A YOUNG, DIVERSE AUDIENCE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO CONNECT THE IMMIGRATION AND MIGRATION STORY AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND SITES IN NEW YORK TO ENHANCE AND EXPAND WORK, LEARNING AND MUSEUM AND INTERPRETATIVE OPPORTUNITIES AT NPS SITES AND THE MUSEUM.THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE FOR THE NPS AND THE LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM TO COLLABORATE ON HISTORIC PRESERVATION, THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND THE ASSOCIATED IMMIGRATION AND MIGRATION STORIES OF THE 17TH THROUGH 21ST CENTURIES. THE TENEMENT MUSEUM WILL OFFER BUILDING TOURS, SPECIFIC VIRTUAL CURATED TOURS AND PROGRAMS AS WELL AS WALKING TOURS EXPLORING THE LOWER EAST SIDE LANDMARKS THAT WERE PART OF THE IMMIGRANT/MIGRANT EXPERIENCES OVER THE LAST 200 HUNDRED YEARSSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE PUBLIC WILL VISIT HISTORIC BUILDINGS DOCUMENTING THE VARIOUS IMMIGRANT AND MIGRANT FAMILIES WHO ACTUALLY LIVED IN THE LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM APARTMENTS FROM THE 1860'S TO THE 1960'S. THE PUBLIC WILL ALSO VISIT SELECT NEIGHBORHOOD TOURS DOCUMENTING THE IMMIGRATION/MIGRATION EXPERIENCES. THE MUSEUM WILL PRESERVE AND MAINTAIN 97 AND 103 ORCHARD STREET, A NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK AND AN NPS-AFFILIATED SITE. THEY WILL CONDUCT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR SCHOOL CHILDREN ANNUALLY, IN GRADES K THROUGH 12, REPRESENTING ITSELF AS AN NPS-AFFILIATED SITE CONDUCTING AN NPS-SUPPORTED PROGRAM AND CONDUCT PUBLIC TOURS REPRESENTING ITSELF AS AN NPS-AFFILIATED SITE CONDUCTING AN NPS-SUPPORTED PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL BUILD NEW AND MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCES FOR ITS NPS-AFFILIATED SITE THROUGH INTERPRETIVE AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE TENEMENT MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE TO OFFER BOTH VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING FOR THE PERIOD OF THIS AGREEMENT DUE TO THE CORONA VIRUS AND IMPACTS ON VISITATION. VIRTUAL AND ON-LINE PROGRAMMING HAS PROVEN TO BE AN EFFECTIVE WAY TO REACH AUDIENCES AND THE MUSEUM CONTINUES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT NEW PROGRAMS.THE MUSEUM IS ALSO EXPANDING HOSTING WALKING TOURS OF NEIGHBORHOODS TO ENHANCE THEIR ABILITY TO CONDUCT OUTSIDE TOURS IN A SAFE MANOR FOR ALL. INDOOR TOURS ARE CONTINUING WITH SMALLER GROUP SIZE AND INCREASED SOCIAL DISTANCING.AT THE SAME TIME, VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING WILL CONTINUE BRINGING THE MUSEUM'S STORYTELLING TO A NATIONAL AUDIENCE. LIVESTREAMED BOOK TALKS TAKE PLACE TWICE PER MONTH AND HIGHLIGHT FACETS OF NEW YORK CITY HISTORY THROUGH INTERVIEWS WITH HISTORIANS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, AND CHEFS. IN ADDITION, THE MUSEUM WILL LIVESTREAM A MONTHLY "TENEMENT TALK" FROM INSIDE ONE OF ITS HISTORIC APARTMENTS. THESE FREE PUBLIC PROGRAMS EXPAND ON TOUR CONTENT THROUGH CONVERSATIONS WITH SCHOLARS, WRITERS, AND ARTISTS. NEW DIGITAL EXHIBITS HOSTED ON THE WEBSITE WILL PROVIDE MULTIMEDIA EXPLORATIONS OF MUSEUM CONTENT.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC AND SCHOOL CHILDREN - BOTH IN PERSON AND VIRTUAL, WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS AGREEMENT. THE NPS AND TENEMENT MUSEUM STAFF MUTUALLY BENEFIT FROM THIS AGREEMENT, WITH EDUCATIONAL AND CROSS TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS THE BOARD. FUTURE GENERATIONS WILL BENEFIT BY THE PRESERVATION AND INTERPRETATION OF THESE SITES DOCUMENTING IMMIGRANT AND MIGRANT FAMILIES FOR GENERATIONS TO COME.

THE PURPOSE OF THE FELLOWSHIP IS TO ENCOURAGE BROADER KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF AMERICAN ARCHITECTURE, PROVIDE TRAINING IN THE RESEARCH OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES, PROVIDE DOCUMENTATION OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES FOR PRESERVATION AND OTHER STEWARDSHIP PURPOSES, AND TO PROVIDE SCHOLARLY KNOWLEDGE. THE STUDENT SELECTED AS THE FELLOW WILL PREPARE A HISTORIC AMERICAN BUILDINGS SURVEY REPORT, AVAILABLE COPYRIGHT FREE TO THE PUBLIC, THROUGH THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS COLLECTION.THIS REPORT WILL IMPROVE THE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF A HISTORIC SITE AND INCREASEAWARENESS REGARDING HISTORIC PRESERVATION WHILE AT THE SAME TIME ALLOWING THE STUDENT TOGAIN HANDS ON EXPERIENCE AND KNOWLEDGE IN DOCUMENTING HISTORIC STRUCTURES.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE BACKGROUND EXPERIENCE BY WHICH EMERGING PROFESSIONALS MAY MAKE LONG-TERM CAREER GOALS AND DECISIONS.
